channel.title: Digital Humanities in WW2 Photography
channel.description: A Principals of Digital Humanities research project

item.title: Introduction
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.content:encoded:
Photo: D 12691 from the IWM collections1

Welcome to our project!

This website summarises our research into a collection of photographs on the Imperial War Museum (IWM) titled Women in World War 2. You can find the link to this source here.

Our objective is to consider Women's contributions to the British War effort between 1939 and 1945.

Women contributed extensively to wartime production, civil defence, and social support, yet visual documentation of this is reflected in selective narratives shaped by institutions and photographers.

This study investigates how women’s roles were depicted, who produced these images, and which communities or experiences may have been marginalised or omitted.

The Imperial War Museum photos, if deemed misrepresentative, could be part of the hegemonic domain* in the matrix of domination* 2

Please enjoy our website! All terms marked with a * will be defined in our glossary.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [{"id":"8aa7dfc0-e336-4b9a-8f8f-5dfdd14ba971","content":"'IWM Collections', Imperial War Museum (2025) <https:\/\/www.iwm.org.uk\/collections\/search?query=&pageSize=30&media-records=records-with-media&filters%5BperiodString%5D%5BSecond%20World%20War%5D=on&filters%5BtermString%5D%5Bwomen%5D=on&style=image&page=8> [Accessed 9 December 2025]."},{"id":"4a6e3437-5115-4d18-9e39-ad1c96c809f3","content":"Catherine D'Ignazio, Lauren Klein,\u00a0<em>Data Feminism<\/em>\u00a0(The MIT Press, 2020), p.25, <https:\/\/soton.idm.oclc.org\/login?url=https:\/\/search.ebscohost.com\/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nlebk&AN=2378911&site=ehost-live>\u00a0 [Accessed 25th Nov 2025]."}]

item.title: cropped-logo-group-prject.png
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.content:encoded: https://womeninww2project.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/cropped-logo-group-prject.png

item.title: Women's Work In Britain During WW2
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Research Aim:

What types of work did women perform in Britain during World War II, as represented in IWM’s photographic archive?

Our primary objective with this project was to shed light on the brilliant work done by women in World War Two. In Invisible Women, Caroline Criado-Perez highlights the expanse of the gender data gap, claiming in her introduction that “because women aren’t seen and aren’t remembered, because male data makes up the majority of what we know, what is male comes to be seen as universal.”1 Her writing highlights the history of exclusion women have repeatedly faced from health and social research and urges readers to break the pattern. This project diverges from the systematic reinforcement of the gender data gap by exploring and drawing attention to the representation of women in World War II archives.

Our project aims to expand the existing data on women, highlighting the diverse range of jobs women undertook during World War II. Over the course of the Second World War, the number of women in the working population increased from 5,094,000 to 7,253,000.2 The war created an increase in demand for jobs, and those of good health and working age were conscripted; naturally, over 2 million women had to fill this gap in the job market.

The word cloud above shows the range of different jobs women were photographed doing in our sample. Overall, the metadata shows 84 jobs recorded across our 150 photographs. The food production chain was widely represented in the dataset, showing women in agriculture, cooking, and distribution. Additionally, the most common job in our images was different types of munitions production, supplying the front line with materials that directly contributed to Britain’s victory.

Representing women’s military work during this period is particularly important due to the taboo surrounding the topic, as post-war Britain developed. Dorothy Sheridan understands the complexities of discussing military work as a woman during the 1980s. Women had to navigate sensitive ground. While she notes, women could openly take pride in having succeeded in jobs once seen as male, such as driving trucks, maintaining equipment, operating radar, or feeding large groups under pressure. It was harder to admit to enjoying the uniform, the drills, or the fact that their work contributed to enemy deaths. It was also difficult to acknowledge, as one woman did in her research, that they might have preferred a military career over the expected path of marriage and motherhood, especially when that later life included children they could not imagine wishing away.3

Sheridan also notes that the scarcely documented history of women in uniform has generally been left to male military historians or to the women soldiers themselves.4 Our project was completed by a dual-gendered and multi-disciplined group, ensuring that we incorporate awareness of intersectionality into our research. The drop-down below shows a timeline of women's rights since World War II.

How perspectives on women in the military changed over time

A Timeline based on information collected from the National Army Museum5

  • 1941: Members of the ATS are no longer considered volunteers and are awarded full credit for their work
  • 1941: The conscription of women becomes legal
  • 1945: VE Day, 190,000 women are members of the ATS
  • 1949: The Women's Royal Army Corps is formed as a successor to the ATS
  • 1975: The Sex Discrimination Act ensures the continued exclusion of women from combat roles
  • 1992: The Women's Royal Army Corps is disbanded, and members are merged with a multi-gender sector
  • 1999: Women's exclusion from certain roles in the military is contested in the European Court of Justice
  • 2002: Women are still deemed unfit for service as a Ministry of Defence study concludes that women in ground combat roles could affect ‘unit cohesion’.
  • 2014: The Women in Close Combat Review Paper recommends ending the ban on women in front-line infantry and armoured corps roles.
  • 2015: Prime Minister announces that all armed forces roles will be open to women.
  • 2018: British Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson announces that all combat roles are open to women, including infantry and special forces units.

(p.38)\u00a0<http:\/\/www.jstor.org\/stable\/40179138> [Accessed 4 Dec. 2025]."},{"id":"9ad473ed-0ce9-41c6-b028-8848a6ec2303","content":"Dorothy Sheridan, 'Ambivalent Memories: Women and the 1939-45 War in Britain',\u00a0<em>Oral History<\/em>, vol. 18, no. 1 (1990) pp. 32\u201340. (p.38)\u00a0<http:\/\/www.jstor.org\/stable\/40179138> [Accessed 4 Dec. 2025]."},{"id":"fd28a3cc-496a-4edd-9895-2da90d1bbfe6","content":"National Army Museum (2025).\u00a0<em>A timeline of women in the Army<\/em>. Available at:\u00a0https:\/\/www.nam.ac.uk\/explore\/timeline-women-army (Accessed: 14 December 2025)"}]

item.title: Revealing perspectives through metadata
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Research Aim:

What can the available metadata reveal about the photographers’ gender and perspectives? (challenge power)

When we first started this project the most important aspect to consider was the metadata fields necessary to include that would shape the outcomes we would come to. It can be considered the cornerstone for which our conclusions rely upon and the reason this project is possible.

Johanna Drucker describes three common functions of metadata: descriptive, administrative and operational1. This project relies upon descriptive metadata, information about an object that "provides the labels for those entities and the organizational system in which they are stored."2 Using metadata in this form allowed us to analyse information about the photos that would be necessary to reach the original aims we set out to achieve.

Drucker posits the idea that "Without metadata, information in files would be like books without covers or title pages on shelves without labels."3. The extraction of metadata from the photos gave us the information needed to let us analyse the deeper roles of women during WWII and their representation within the IWM’s collection. The metadata fields we chose were catered not only to the information we wanted to gather, but also included other fields such as the type of material the photo was on to ensure reusability of the dataset gathered.

Photos taken in war, specifically by government bodies, are never just about documenting the situations and hardships that soldiers or civilians found themselves in. Photos allowed the government to convey meaning to the people through the reliable use of propaganda, as Urvashi Gautam states "In a state of total war, which required civilians to participate in the war effort, morale came to be recognised as a significant military factor, and propaganda slowly emerged as the principle instrument of control over public opinion and as an essential weapon in the national arsenal."4 While posters are the main thought one might consider when viewing propaganda, it was an act that was carried out in many forms to achieve the best desired effect from the public. Gautam presents that propaganda in Britain tried to achieve a strong sense of "do their part", showing either photos of battles or contributors giving to the war effort5. Many of the photos our project chose from the IWM collection take this form, showcasing women in key roles contributing to the war effort and "doing their part".

The inclusion of metadata about the gender of the photographer (if available) allows our project to challenge and examine power in the IWM collection. First it is important to consider the matrix of domination (glossary term) present in this collection. Of the four domains the hegemonic domain appears here, ‘the realm of culture, media, and ideas.’, the IWM collection presents these photos in the broad categories of ‘WWII’ and ‘Women’, with little documentation on the reasons they have behind placing these photos in these categories. As seen in the bar chart the photos taken were either by male photographers that can be identified or a N/A gender. In the case of N/A it stems from many of the photos not being linked to specific people, instead shown as being taken by government positions such as ‘Ministry of Information Photo Division Photographer’ or ‘Ministry of Information official photographer’. The IWM collection does not give any further information about who these people might be.

item.title: Absence and Underrepresentation of Women of colour
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Research Aim:

How might women of colour and other marginalised groups be underrepresented or absent in the dataset, and what does this suggest about archival bias?

When adhering to the principles of data feminism, it is important to challenge power and consider the outcomes that arise from a collection of war photographs taken predominantly by white, male photographers.

D’Ignazio and Klein highlight the existence of “structural privilege” (e.g., the white male photographers and government officials during WWII) and “structural oppression,” in which some demographics are better represented because “systems have been designed by people like them and work for people like them.”1 As the graph demonstrates, Black women are largely excluded from our primary dataset. This reflects the structural bias in the dataset and the systematic oppression present in the United Kingdom in the 20th century.

The “colour bar”2 in the British military is a major reason why so few images of Black women exist in the IWM photographs. Before World War II, Black people were not permitted to join the army; however, this restriction was mostly lifted in 1939. In the Auxiliary Territorial Service, where many of our photographs were taken, people of colour remained racially excluded until 19433.

The National Archives note that after the colour bar was lifted, there were several hundred Afro-Caribbean ATS recruits.4 Since 35% (1 d.p.) of our data sample contains images taken in 1943, 1944, or 1945, it is still unrepresentative that only 1 out of 150 images depicts Black women contributing to the British war effort.

These contexts are not noted in the Imperial War Museum collection and may have gone unnoticed without being highlighted via our spreadsheet and data visualisations. This is a clear example of how the principles of digital humanities can assist the ethical handling of data in research.

item.title: Glossary
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
FAIR- Responsible principles of Digital Humanities. Acronym standing for Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable.1

CARE- Ethical principles of Digital Humanities for Indigenous Data Governance. Acronym standing for Collective Benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility and Ethics.2

Metadata- the sum total of what one can say at a given moment about any information object at any level of aggregation3. Data contextualising data.

Hegemonic Domain- culture and media that circulates oppressive ideas4.

Matrix of domination- A system of explaining how power is configured and experienced. Consists of four domains: structural domain, disciplinary domain, hegemonic domain and interpersonal domain. 5

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [{"id":"b271669c-241e-4cb5-b93f-431cffc98694","content":"'FAIR Principles', GO FAIR (2016) <https:\/\/www.go-fair.org\/fair-principles\/> [Accessed 9 December 2025]."},{"id":"fc78608c-7dba-4e44-8cf3-63baf70bd795","content":"'CARE Principles', GIDA (2018) <https:\/\/www.gida-global.org\/care> [Accessed 9 December 2025]."},{"id":"4f598e45-58d5-42a9-8351-dfd8198f9992","content":"Setting the stage', GETTY <https:\/\/www.getty.edu\/publications\/intrometadata\/setting-the-stage\/> [Accessed 9 December 2025]."},{"id":"9af74a30-2604-438e-8245-94745cf521bd","content":"D'Ignazio, Catherine and Klein, Lauren,\u00a0<em>Data Feminism<\/em>\u00a0(The MIT Press, 2020), p.25, <https:\/\/soton.idm.oclc.org\/login?url=https:\/\/search.ebscohost.com\/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nlebk&AN=2378911&site=ehost-live>\u00a0 [Accessed 25th Nov 2025]"},{"id":"a0608df1-ce46-4a9c-8fbd-e5b3d0478cf3","content":"D'Ignazio, Catherine and Klein, Lauren,\u00a0<em>Data Feminism<\/em>\u00a0(The MIT Press, 2020), p.25, <https:\/\/soton.idm.oclc.org\/login?url=https:\/\/search.ebscohost.com\/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nlebk&AN=2378911&site=ehost-live>\u00a0 [Accessed 25th Nov 2025]"}]

item.title: Environmental Considerations
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
With growing greenhouse gases in the environment today it is important to assess how best to limit the carbon footprint a project will have. Information and communication technology accounts for an estimated 2.1% - 3.9%1 of all greenhouse gas emissions, and so it necessary to account for thorough behaviours and practices to reduce this amount.

One way we have aimed to reduce our footprint is by limiting the physical means needed to support our project, cutting out the reliance on using equipment that would need to be continuously maintained to ensure operability. Instead, we chose to use a website hosting platform that would eliminate this need for physical hardware.

Through the website carbon calculator we can see that our website has an A+ score and is cleaner than 99% of websites globally. One problem that is highlighted, however is the use of bog-standard energy instead of renewable green sources of energy. This is one of the few downsides of hosting a website through WordPress and is one of the limitations we have found with our project. Yet WordPress does have a ‘Hosting Team Handbook’ with a section titled ‘Sustainability for Hosts’ that outlines useful guidelines to adhere to in the hopes of reducing the environmental impact of hosting a website.

In response to this we have tried to limit the footprint of our project as much as possible using green coding techniques(glossary). We have kept the website to a simplistic design that, while matching the theme of WWII to elicit cohesion, keeps to a minimalistic profile that conveys the information effectively instead of through numerous flashy images and colour that would increase the footprint.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [{"id":"b7a06f9d-80b4-463e-98b6-42a2c74497ad","content":"Benjamin C. Lee, 'A view of the sustainable computing landscape', <em>Patterns<\/em>, 6.7 (2025), pp. 1-6, <strong>DOI:<\/strong><a href=\"https:\/\/dx.doi.org\/10.1016\/j.patter.2025.101296\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">10.1016\/j.patter.2025.101296<\/a> "}]

item.title: Outcomes
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Overall, our metadata spreadsheet was an effective method of exploring the wide range of women’s roles in employment and domestic assistance during the Second World War. Compiling the data in an XML spreadsheet made the Imperial War Museum data interoperable for analysis in data visualisations, which clearly demonstrated a plethora of different job roles as intended by our original project.  As a result, we contributed to a gender data gap by providing additional insight into women during WW2.

Our dataset also revealed some discrepancies in the ethical production of the IWM photographs. Using the Principles of Data Feminism, we examined power, discovering that all recorded photographers of the images were white men. We then challenged this systemic power, considering what effect a male photographer had on the representation of women and minorities in the images. 

Having collected and analysed this data, we considered ethical methods of storing the data in alliance with the FAIR principles. Consequently, we stored our dataset and website on the digital repository, GitHub. This can be found here:

https://github.com/groupproject14/Digitial-Humanities-Research-Project-Women-in-WW2

We then made a WordPress website to present our findings and methodology, ensuring that we considered environmental data implications and used a static, plain website design.

Thank you for visiting our project!

item.title: Credits
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Alex serves as the group’s coordinator and recorder. She documented each bi-weekly meeting, providing clear email summaries that outline discussion points, decisions, and agreed next steps. Alex was responsible for producing the initial draft of written submissions after thorough discussion with Freddie, ensuring that all ideas are accurately represented. In addition, she contributed to metadata entry for the project dataset. She wrote half of the website pages and made our logo.

Freddie oversaw project management and quality assurance. He ensured that tasks are distributed equitably and adjusts his data-entry workload to reflect the team’s overall balance of responsibilities. Freddie reviewed and refined final drafts of written work to maintain a high standard of submissions. He also acted as the group’s critical evaluator, helping to assess ideas and determine the most effective approaches to our project. He made our data visualisations and wrote half of the website pages.

item.title: Hello World!
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress! This is your first post. Edit or delete it to take the first step in your blogging journey.

item.title: Header
item.dc:creator: freddiewbworld
item.content:encoded:
Digital Humanities in World War Two Photography

•

Welcome to our digital humanities research project exploring narratives of Women's contribution to the British war effort during World War Two

item.title: Index
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.excerpt:encoded: Used as a fallback template for all pages when a more specific template is not defined.

item.title: Footer
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25

item.title: Absence and Underrepresentation of Women of colour
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.content:encoded:
Research Aim:

How might women of colour and other marginalised groups be underrepresented or absent in the dataset, and what does this suggest about archival bias?

When adhering to the principles of data feminism, it is important to challenge power and consider the outcomes that arise from a collection of war photographs taken predominantly by white, male photographers.

D’Ignazio and Klein highlight the existence of “structural privilege” (e.g., the white male photographers and government officials during WWII) and “structural oppression,” in which some demographics are better represented because “systems have been designed by people like them and work for people like them.”1 As the graph demonstrates, Black women are largely excluded from our primary dataset. This reflects the structural bias in the dataset and the systematic oppression present in the United Kingdom in the 20th century.

The “colour bar”2 in the British military is a major reason why so few images of Black women exist in the IWM photographs. Before World War II, Black people were not permitted to join the army; however, this restriction was mostly lifted in 1939. In the Auxiliary Territorial Service, where many of our photographs were taken, people of colour remained racially excluded until 19433.

The National Archives note that after the colour bar was lifted, there were several hundred Afro-Caribbean ATS recruits.4 Since 35% (1 d.p.) of our data sample contains images taken in 1943, 1944, or 1945, it is still unrepresentative that only 1 out of 150 images depicts Black women contributing to the British war effort.

These contexts are not noted in the Imperial War Museum collection and may have gone unnoticed without being highlighted via our spreadsheet and data visualisations. This is a clear example of how the principles of digital humanities can assist the ethical handling of data in research.

item.title: Methodology
item.dc:creator: alexandracgiles25
item.content:encoded:
Firstly, we selected 150 digitised photographs sourced from the Imperial War Museum’s open-access digital collection. The images were selected according to the following criteria:

  • Each image must depict a woman engaged in essential wartime labour (defined as work contributing directly to Britain’s war effort or to sustaining civilian life). Examples include munitions production, farming, medical care, and childcare.

The project will employ FAIR* and CARE* principles to ensure ethical handling of digital data.

In accordance with accessibility and reusability principles, the IWM photographs are available under a Non-Commercial use licence. This means for:

  • Personal use for non-commercial research and private study, and other uses under the UK’s exceptions to copyright and those exceptions to copyright in place where the user is located.
  • Use on websites that are primarily information-led, research-oriented and not behind a paywall.1

We have extracted the images from a collection of photographs categorised as ‘WW2’ and ‘Women’ on the IWM website; therefore, the categorisation of these subjects as women is not our own process but that of the IWM.

For each photograph, we recorded metadata* fields including image title, description, date, photographer, subject activity, race (where identifiable), and photographic type. This information has been collated into a structured dataset for analysis. Here is the download link to our dataset (excluding the race column for reasons related to GDPR):

women-in-ww2-project-metadata-copy-for-websiteDownload

We then followed a process of data cleaning to ensure that we used cohesive terminology throughout the dataset. Terms such as 'munitions' and 'ammunitions', 'farming' and 'agriculture' and formatting the catalogue numbers in the same manner.

Once our dataset was complete, Freddie oversaw our data visualisation using RawGraphs to create bar charts that reveal trends in photographer demographics and representation. He also used Wordclouds.co.uk to generate a word cloud depicting the wide range of actions we recorded in our metadata.

Secondary sources, including existing discourse on wartime photography and women’s history, will support the interpretation of our results, allowing for both quantitative and qualitative insights.

We have stored our website and dataset in a GitHub digital repository found here:

https://github.com/groupproject14/Digitial-Humanities-Research-Project-Women-in-WW2
